Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I stared at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing insistently. This was the final team discussion before we locked in the project’s direction, and my manager had stressed how important everyone’s input was. As a colleague, I was expected to be there, to contribute, to show my commitment to the team. But I was already on a train, heading across the state to my family’s village. The festival was one of the most important in our tradition, and my parents had been clear: I was needed for the rituals, to help with the offerings, to be present in every sense. My mind raced with the weight of both expectations. If I missed the meeting, would my team see me as unreliable? If I skipped the festival, would my family feel I was turning my back on our faith? The train rattled on, and I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between two worlds that both demanded all of me.
